fields.headline: The  prize   quiz
fields.bodyText: Dermot Murnaghan has spent most of his career in broadcast journalism. He currently presents BBC Breakfast News and before joining the BBC, he fronted ITV's national news bulletins. His latest project is Word 4 Word, a new Radio 4 series about dialect and local speech in Britain. Word 4 Word begins on Wednesday August 3, part of the BBC's Voices season. Each week, a different guest quizmaster sets five questions per day, Monday to Friday. Send us your answers to all 25 questions at the end of the week and the first correct entry out of the hat will win a £100 electronic gift card from Borders (www.bordersstores.co.uk). E1 Which of these words means "tadpole"? a) Pollywiggle b) Pot-ladle c) Poddle-ladle d) All of the above E2 In the Midlands, what does "proper poorly" mean? a) Very unwell b) Having little or no money c) Unlucky d) Mistaking a person for someone else E3 In Liverpool, what does "skitter" mean? a) To skid on a bike or motorbike b) To play tenpin bowling c) To fall over d) To verbally abuse E4 For the Voices season, how many people's voices have been captured by BBC journalists? a) More than 1,200 b) 350 c) 12 million d) 12 E5 Which of these words means "out of date"? a) Antwacky b) Daggy c) Square d) All of the above Entries must reach Prize Quiz, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by Wednesday August 3. The winner will be notified on August 5. One entry per person. No purchase necessary. The daily online news quiz is at: theguardian.com/quiz
